body: LGTM, the Jenkins failures seem irrelevant and transient. Also made a passing Ducktape system test build on this branch. @hachikuji Please remember to address @becketqin 's comments in the later follow-up path. Merging this large patch for now as it is getting very large.
Also, in JaasUtils.isZkSecurityEnabled(), do we still need to check a separate "zookeeper.sasl.client" system property?
Could you rebase again? Guozhang just pushed a big patch on the new consumer.
Jun - Rebased.
Thanks for the patch. LGTM

To give an example, suppose the logEndOffset of the given partition on the leader and followers are 10, 8, 10. If the consumer reads uncommitted message from the follower with logEndOffset 10, then in the fetchResponse we may have:

```
partitionData.highWatermark - newOffset = 8 - 10 < 0
```

This is found that the `buffer.capacity()` would be reflecting the underlying whole byte buffer's capacity, and hence cannot be reliably used for readable records. Renamed some other APIs for better clarity and a minor behavior fix for `hasRoomFor`. Ping @junrao for reviews.

@guozhangwang If you have a chance to look at this, I'm not sure when @gwenshap will be able to get to it. Includes updated system test to validate it _really_ works in distributed mode.

There's one fix for AbstractCoordinator that may end up being resolved in a different JIRA, but is needed here. We'll have to coordinate with @hachikuji to figure out what order these need to be committed in.

@junrao I am fine with adding sasl + ssl test for end to end coverage, not sure if we want to do that in this single jira. There is a setup overhead for both 2 way ssl and Sasl with MiniKDC. I can refactor this test so it will be a super class, we can establish server identities in the extension of this test class and the base class will have all the tests that will execute for each type of identity. 

That being said, I am not sure if this test is really the right place to do any of that. How we establish identity is irrelevant to the authorizer because as long as authorizer gets some identity we have enough testing around it to ensure it will do the authorization correctly. With the recommended tests, we are just going to test that right identities will be established which in my opinion should be tested as part of sasl or ssl testing.
@SinghAsDev which gradle command failed on your machine?
@guozhangwang I ran "gradle clean build -x test"

I agree with Jun that an end to end test would be useful. In my opinion, it doesn't have to test all the endpoints, but it should check that the different pieces work well together. Having said that, I think it could be done in a separate JIRA. It would be really good to get the fixes in this PR merged.
There's something weird going on here. I run checkstyle all the time and I don't get these failures. Are you sure you are not overriding the checkstyle settings in some way?
@SinghAsDev I reran your command locally and it works fine. Did you override the checkstyle.xml somehow?

It could be a Gradle version problem? Is there a reason why you are using `gradle` instead of `gradlew` which handles versioning correctly?
Thanks for the patch. LGTM
It works fine with gradlew, however, the styling errors caught look legitimate to me. What do you guys think?
Given the merge conflicts that this would cause, I think we should only go in this direction if we are also interested in changing the checkstyle rules to match.

I agree that in unit tests, it's enough to just verify that we can get the expected user name on the broker side through either SSL or SASL. This can be done in a separate jira. Just left a couple of more comments above.
@guozhangwang do you mind giving this a quick review?
Thanks for the patch. LGTM
From the logs it seems you are using Gradle 2.1, could you try at least Gradle 2.4 to see if it is still the case (we have just upgraded the default version to 2.8 by @ijuma).
@ewencp @guozhangwang I added [KAFKA-2683](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-2683) to address the wakeup issue.

LGTM. Just to clarify, this issue was only affecting replica fetcher's lag metrics; for normal consumers, since they are always consuming from leaders up to HW the lag metric should never be negative.
@ewencp Ready for another pass

@ijuma you are correct, this will lead to merge conflicts. Given that it is not an issue with correct gradle version, and we document to use ./gradlew anyways, I will go ahead and close this. Thanks for your time @guozhangwang and @ijuma

During my rebase, I seem to have introduced an error in the quotas test case with 2 consumers: as far as I can tell, the jmx process starts on second consumer node, but the `jmx_tools.log` is empty (no stats are collected from the consumer process).

Thanks for the patch. LGTM. Just a few minor comments.

@granders Sure, I am happy to review the code. @ewencp has made many comments and I agree with them. Can I look through the code all over again after you address his comments?

Also, can you tell me which test has the problem you described? I will pull your branch and test it on my side -- this may help me identify the problem.
@ijuma @guozhangwang ping for review

@guozhangwang @becketqin @ewencp I did a little renaming as suggested by Becket. I decided to change the callback names used in AbstractCoordinator to reflect the current usage. As such, `onLeave` was changed to `onJoinPrepare`, and `onJoin` was changed to `onJoinComplete`. We can probably consider separately whether these are the semantics we want to have, but for now it seems best to make the names consistent with the implementation.
@guozhangwang Thanks for the review. I addressed you comments. It looks the test failure is irrelevant. Mind take another look?
LGTM.

@fpj, here's a PR with some suggestions: https://github.com/fpj/kafka/pull/1

Keep in mind that I did not test it. Feel free to use some ideas, merge it or reject it. :)
@gwenshap Could you review? Would like to get this committed. I'd also like to get #354 in, but that will require me to rebase yet again... (though it would be an easy rebase)

Let me think about this for a bit more - originally I thought we should only count the metrics under the kafka-metrics package. I think we should eventually move away from yammer metrics but I think the latest approach of just reporting the total number of mbeans may subsume that and may be useful by itself.

I think recording the total number of mbeans is probably not right. In terms of debugging, we care about how many metrics are coming from kafka. Recording the total number of mbeans doesn't really help us if there's a ton of mbeans being made outside of kafka.

For instance, let's say an application has two clients: a KafkaConsumer and a client for some other KV store. If the KV store client mbeans start going through the roof, it can incorrectly get classified as a kafka problem.

Regarding logging vs print, I think for things that we want to show the end users, we probably shouldn't be depending on log4j since if the users changed the log4j setting, we still want the end users to see the output. Once we print those messages, is there a need to log it in log4j? The printed message will show up during tests as well. Plus, for users who do use the log4j setting that's out of box, they will now see duplicated messages since the default setting shows error logging.

One alternative is to only have the listener at the `ConsumerNetworkClient` level and change the result type of `NetworkClient.poll`. I thought that this would be invasive, but it was actually really simple. Here's a commit that shows what I mean:

https://github.com/ijuma/kafka/commit/2e654d9e58fd7466097950c94b5bb52014c917b3

The code compiles although I commented out some test code since I just meant to demonstrate the idea. Naming could probably be improved.

I think this approach fits better with the NetworkClient design and, as Jason pointed out, we don't have to worry about semantics for the case where the listener invokes NetworkClient methods.

Jason suggested that I should ask for @guozhangwang's input.

+1 on @ijuma's suggestion. I like this idea since it keeps the NetworkClient API "in front of you," so to speak. I wasn't sure if listener semantics is really something we want to introduce to NetworkClient, since it is so widely used in the codebase.
@gwenshap @hachikuji Updated to address all the review comments.

@hachikuji Thanks. I think the names look much better now. I agree with your comments in #165 that it would be great if we can have the methods in rebalance listener to be consistent. Do you also want to change the name in ConsumerRebalanceListener? If we decide to do so, we'd better do this now than after 0.9 release.

@guozhangwang @ewencp What do you think?

LGTM too.

Re: RebalanceListener, I just find the current behavior confusing because you get onPartitionsRevoked before you are even a member of the group, right? I think renaming could help. In the distributed Copycat patch, the equivalent just has different semantics -- the WorkerRebalanceListener.onRevoked method is only invoked if you actually _owned_ something that needed to be revoked. 

I think in the consumer we've just been leaning on the the fact that the empty assignment list from the subscriptions generally makes this work ok (whereas in Copycat you'd get a null pointer exception if you hadn't gone through the join process yet).

In any case, that shouldn't block this patch, just some additional thoughts on it since these are all related. That said, I think the ConsumerRebalanceListener semantics are more important to get right since it's public interface.

@becketqin @ewencp Yep, I'm on board with changing the callback names in ConsumerRebalanceListener (I also wonder if we can drop the 'Consumer' as well?). Would it make more sense to do that in a patch to KAFKA-2674 than here?
Thanks for the patch. LGTM

LGTM.

Learned a lot about the new coordinator feature on the way :)

Pinging for doc update :)
@omkreddy any updates? this also needs rebasing
See PR #337. Sorry for not updating sooner. Github shows the relationship on my side.
Why not use `getConfiguration()` like we do for the SASL code?

I would have liked to use `getConfiguration()` to load the configuration specified using the System property `java.security.auth.login.config`. But `kafka.admin.ZkSecurityMigrator` has two ways of specifying the config file, the system property is overridden by an option. I wasn't sure why the option is required and didn't want to break it. 

I was also worried about changing the current behaviour because of `Configuration.setConfiguration(null)` at the end of the method `isZkSecurityEnabled` with the comment `Tests fail if we don't reset the login configuration. It is unclear what is actually triggering this bug.`.
LGTM except one minor comment.

@ijuma @hachikuji Just another idea I had before: we can check "coordinator alive" in each `poll` call instead of "coordinator known", i.e. checking `this.coordinator != null && !client.connectionFailed(this.coordinator)` in the AbstractCoordinator. The motivation is that as long as consumers does `poll` regularly (and they should in order to heartbeat anyways), we can still detect coordinator disconnection in time.

Re: RebalanceListener, I would prefer the current function names just as @becketqin pointed out, since they are belonging to the Kafka consumer that are exposed to users who are mostly interested in the assigned partitions only, while `AbstractAssignor` and `AbstractCoordinator` APIs are exposed to programmers which are interested in general coordinator protocol. So changing the former's function names to be related to `Join` might confuse users who are not familiar with the protocol itself.

@guozhangwang I agree that the RebalanceListener should probably not refer directly to joining. That said, it would be nice to have names which suggested the actual semantics that are implemented so that we don't have issues like KAFKA-2674. Maybe we could rename `onPartitionsRevoked` to `onRebalancePrepare`, and `onPartitionsAssigned` to `onRebalanceComplete`? That would be consistent with this patch without introducing any unnecessary concepts to the user. In fact, since the interface name is already `RebalanceListener`, maybe we could make this even more concise and use `onPrepare` and `onComplete`.

@guozhangwang That might work. The tricky thing about using connectionFailed() is that the disconnected state will persist until it is cleared with a call to ready() (after the backoff time has elapsed). But maybe we could solve that by always calling ready() when we discover the coordinator in the group metadata response handler.

I think we should remove that option in `ZkSecurityMigrator` and just leave the system property. I believe that is what @junrao had suggested in the PR too. @fpj, is there a strong reason to allow a different way of specifying the JAAS file? I know that it's a bit nicer for command-line users, but If we do that, we need to implement JDK-specific code like @rajinisivaram did in this PR. And using the system property is consistent across broker, clients and tools.

I agree that it may be useful to record and report the total number of attributes. The main concern I have in the current approach is that each lookup for this metric (from some metric pulling system) will involve a traversal of the mbean registry which is a bit much if the lookup happens frequently. There are a couple of ways to avoid this/improve it:
- Cache the count and avoid updating the count unless a certain period (e.g., a few minutes) has elapsed
- Trap mbean registrations/deregistrations and increment/decrement counts there
- Dont count all mbean attributes - instead, only count Kafka metric attributes. i.e., back to your earlier approach.

@guozhangwang I think the tradeoff with this approach is that we'll only detect disconnects after we try to send something, which means detection will typically be limited by the heartbeat duration. That might be a reasonable trade since the approach is simpler.
@guozhangwang Rebased for Ewen's copycat patch. If the changes seem reasonable, maybe we can commit this and address RebalanceListener in KAFKA-2674?

@datalorax @SinghAsDev Sorry for the delay on this. I was a little more optimistic before that KAFKA-2017 would be committed prior to 0.9, but it's now looking like it will be pushed. So I created KIP-40, which proposes to modify the group metadata request to support this use case. With that proposal, fetching all the consumer groups in the cluster would involve sending group metadata requests to all brokers. It's a little annoying, but I don't see any other options at the moment.
LGTM.

@gwenshap I think the system tests revealed an issue with the `DistributedHerder`. I found the following in [the log](http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_system_tests/ws/results/2015-10-26--001/CopycatDistributedFileTest/test_file_source_and_sink/CopycatDistributedService/worker4/copycat.log/*view*/) from the [failed test](http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_system_tests/ws/results/2015-10-26--001/):

```
[2015-10-26 07:18:58,865] INFO Joined group and got assignment: Assignment{error=0, leader='12368506-92ce-4a11-a096-d2988b00b9f3', offset=6, connectorIds=[local-file-source, local-file-sink], taskIds=[]} (org.apache.kafka.copycat.runtime.distributed.DistributedHerder:614)
[2015-10-26 07:20:22,572] INFO Copycat stopping (org.apache.kafka.copycat.runtime.Copycat:64)
```

It looks like the worker joined the group, got an assignment, but then didn't do anything with it. Eventually the test ended and it was shut down.

I think what happened is that the rejoin happened in the call to `member.poll()`. Since this happens before the `selector.poll()` and now actually using that assignment is deferred, if we have a large timeout on the `poll()`, we might get this assignment and then sleep in the poll for a long time. Instead, we should make sure we always trigger a wakeup to ensure we immediately process the assignment.

@hachikuji Wouldn't mind a sanity check & review from you too.
My concern with `onPrepare` is that it takes the revoked partitions as its parameter which is a bit confusing with the function name itself.

@hachikuji I think a) we need to respect the connection backoff even for coordinator; which means if the coordinator has disconnected, and we discover it is still the coordinator, while reconnecting we still need to wait until backoff is elapsed. b) since the disconnects are only detected inside the selector, for any of these approaches we are limited to selector's behavior that we can only detect disconnections when we select on that channel's key.
LGTM

@hachikuji Could you double check if this patch is compatible with the latest trunk as we have some recent merges that depend on this API which may not actually result in conflicts detectable by Github.
